{"step_by_step_thinking": "The relevant information states that HbS migrates more slowly toward the anode (positive electrode) than HbA during electrophoresis at alkaline pH. This is because HbS has a substitution of glutamic acid with valine, resulting in the absence of negatively charged glutamate residues in the two β chains, making HbS less negative than HbA. Therefore, the mobility of HbS is decreased compared to normal hemoglobin (HbA).", "answer_choice": "A"}
